author: By Alan Blinder
title: Wyndham Clark Captures the U.S. Open
description: Clark, with only one PGA Tour victory to his name, seemed to come out of nowhere to dominate the field at Los Angeles Country Club.
content: Two Tuesdays ago, as the golf world erupted into chaos and fury, Wyndham Clark did not rush to write a shock-and-awe Twitter post. He did not fume in a meeting with the PGA Tour commissioner about the surprise pact with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund. He did not moralize or criticize or, really, do much of anything other than play golf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Syren Nagakyrie
title: Accessible Nature: A Trail Guide for Disabled Hikers
description: We highlight a selection of paths, overlooks and other sites in several U.S. parks that outdoor enthusiasts with disabilities can enjoy this summer.
content: I was well into adulthood when I realized that hiking was an activity that I could participate in. I grew up with multiple disabilities and chronic illnesses and thought being “outdoorsy” was only for able-bodied people. I couldn’t find information about hiking as a disabled person, so I spent a lot of time trying to figure it out for myself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Shifts in global economic policy.
content: After five years of major disruptions — a pandemic, war in Europe, tensions between the U.S. and China, inflation — the global economic outlook has dimmed. And, as the dust settles, many long-held assumptions about the world economy are now being questioned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Sherwood
title: A Walk in Marrakesh: A Spider Web of Passageways
description: The medina, the ancient neighborhood where this Moroccan city was born, offers sensory stimulation at every turn.
content: The wail of snake charmers’ horns will lead you to your departure point: Jemaa El Fna. This carnivalesque, open-air market in the medina — the ancient neighborhood where Marrakesh was born — brims with juice stands, restaurants and souvenir shops, to say nothing of musicians and performers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Let Kids Get Bored. It’s Good for Them.
description: A reminder to parents soldiering through the summer: Boredom has its virtues.
content: I have a few particularly vivid memories of my childhood summers: the smell of the grill, the rattle of the cicadas — and the feeling of being bored out of my mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: And the Winner for the Cate Blanchett Award for Good Acting Is…
description: At the second annual “Las Culturistas” Culture Awards, the comedians Bowen Yang and Matt Rogers put on an affectionate and over-the-top parody of an award show.
content: At the “Las Culturistas” Culture Awards on Saturday night, the winner of the Cate Blanchett Award for Good Acting was … Cate Blanchett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher, Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: China’s Rebound Hits a Wall, and There Is ‘No Quick Fix’ to Revive It
description: Policymakers and investors expected China’s economy to rev up again after Beijing abruptly dropped Covid precautions, but recent data shows alarming signs of a slowdown.
content: When China suddenly dismantled its lockdowns and other Covid precautions last December, officials in Beijing and many investors expected the economy to spring back to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Much Can I Express Myself Through My Work Wardrobe?
description: A reader wonders how to dress appropriately for a corporate internship — without looking “like a drone.”
content: “What you got to understand is, when you come into work, you give up certain rights.” So says Toby Flenderson, the H.R. character in “The Office,” during Season 5, Episode 26 — a.k.a., “Casual Friday.” The specific right he was talking about was, as it happens, the right to dress as you want. And while the show may have been a comedy, his statement was not entirely a joke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Racial Wage Gap Is Shrinking
description: Though still enormous, the gap has shrunk over the past five years.
content: In the early 2000s, the wage gap between Black and white workers in the U.S. was as large as it had been in 1950.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Where Housing Prices Have Crashed and Billions in Wealth Have Vanished
description: In New Zealand, high interest rates have sent property prices sliding nearly 18 percent since November 2021.
content: Michael Wilson was hopeful when he put his three-bedroom house up for sale: Over a dozen would-be buyers came to the initial showing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Ex-Lawyer Who Killed Girlfriend Dies in Custody Days Before Sentencing
description: James Ray III faced a life sentence after being convicted of murder. He was found unconscious in his New Jersey jail cell on Father’s Day.
content: James R. Ray III, a former New York City police officer and lawyer who was awaiting sentencing for murdering his longtime girlfriend, died on Sunday after being found unconscious in a New Jersey jail cell, according to Essex County officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tess Taylor
title: ‘Beowulf’ and Beyond: A Poet Who Embraced Translation
description: As seen in a new collection, “The Translations of Seamus Heaney,” the Nobel laureate was a prolific and skilled interpreter of other poets’ work.
content: Over the past few years, Joe Biden has made much of quoting from Seamus Heaney’s luminous translation of Sophocles’ play “The Cure at Troy”:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: ‘I Can’t Continue This Fight Any Longer’
description: Why Tyrell Terry walked away from basketball, the millions of dollars that came with it and the identity he had spent his whole life building.
content: The aromatic vineyards of Würzburg and the city’s architectural masterpieces hardly registered with Tyrell Terry as he journeyed to the Franconia region of Germany in December. His life in basketball, once a source of joy to him, had collapsed into a debilitating and lonely loop, and he could see little beyond his own misery. He was venturing nearly 5,000 miles mostly because he needed a friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Clements
title: A Walk in Sydney: Sea, Bushland and City Views
description: Take your time along the Hermitage Foreshore track to admire native flora, take in the skyline and swim at secluded beaches.
content: Few cities are so abundant with forest-like parks, coastal walks and beaches as Sydney, which is best explored on foot. If you do one hike here, the Hermitage Foreshore track has it all. The trail offers a side of Sydney’s eastern suburbs most visitors don’t see. Grand old houses meet lush bush, calm water, endless swimming opportunities and a new city view at every turn. It’s uncrowded and relaxed, and despite the blue-chip surrounds, it is delightfully unpretentious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Celia McGee
title: Reframing the West: New Fiction Makes Room for Voices Long Denied
description: A wave of novels is drawing from wellsprings of race, class and gender to expand the genre.
content: Their eyes meet across a crowded street in 1870s Dodge City, Kan., the gunslinging bounty hunter and the impulsive rebel, one a dark-haired loner, the other a striking redhead: two young women destined to work out their mutual sparks on the frontier where Owen Wister enshrined the all-male, all-white Western genre novel with “The Virginian,” in 1902.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: A Savory Stroll Under the Neon Lights of Singapore
description: Mud crabs, skewers, frog porridge and more: Expect an overload for your taste buds along Geylang Road, in the city-state’s red light district.
content: Geylang Road in central Singapore is synonymous with the night, when a dizzying number of neon street signs power on and large groups crowd tables that spill out onto the sidewalk. It’s a tasty spot for a nocturnal stroll, to discover vespertine feasts of local specialties, like crab doused in a bracing white-pepper sauce or steamy porridge showcasing marinated frog legs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Eye on Expo 2030, Rome Dreams of Reinvigoration
description: After years of decline, the city hopes to use a bid for the next world’s fair to re-envision itself as a place that works.
content: Other visitors to the abandoned sports complex on the edge of Rome might just see muddy puddles, graffitied walls and loose cables blighting their view. Not Matteo Gatto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Once Scorned, Far Right Secures Foothold in Spanish Cities
description: Local alliances between the center-right Popular Party and the far-right Vox may foreshadow a broader coalition agreement at the national level.
content: Spain’s far right took office in a string of Spanish cities and in a powerful region over the weekend by forging coalition agreements with the moderate right, in a move that may foreshadow a broader alliance to govern the country after next month’s general elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: N.B.A. Draft Preview: After Victor Wembanyama, Watch for These Players
description: Wembanyama, the French star, is expected to be the top pick. But prospects like Anthony Black of Arkansas and Iowa’s Kris Murray can help teams, too.
content: The only mystery surrounding the top pick in this year’s N.B.A. draft was resolved a month ago. On May 16, the San Antonio Spurs won the draft lottery, giving them the opportunity — or, perhaps more aptly, the obligation — to select Victor Wembanyama with the first overall pick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine retakes some villages but its forces face minefields and more airstrikes.
description: BLAHODATNE, Ukraine — After months of preparation and bolstered by hundreds of donated tanks, armored vehicles and howitzers, Ukraine has notched small successes in the first week and a half of a counteroffensive to drive Russian forces from southern Ukraine.
content: BLAHODATNE, Ukraine — After months of preparation and bolstered by hundreds of donated tanks, armored vehicles and howitzers, Ukraine has notched small successes in the first week and a half of a counteroffensive to drive Russian forces from southern Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Crevar
title: A Walk in Zadar: A Loop Through History
description: A circumnavigation of the city’s Old Town includes a tidal symphony and an architectural synopsis of Croatian history.
content: A nearly two-mile walk circumnavigating Zadar’s Old Town is a journey across a timeline that spans nearly every stage of Croatian history. And it’s a long history, dating back to the 9th century B.C., when the Liburnians first settled this peninsular spit of land on Croatia’s spectacular Dalmatian coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Chris Paul Found Out About the Suns’ Trade From His Son
description: Paul, a 12-time All-Star, was on a promotional tour for a book he wrote about his grandfather and his N.B.A. career.
content: Chris Paul was on a plane to New York on Sunday, to promote his new book, when he heard the news in a text from his 14-year-old son, Chris II: He had been traded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Take Care of Maya’ Review: A Chronicle of a Family’s Pain
description: In this Netflix documentary about a young girl who was held in a hospital and barred from seeing her family, we hear their side of the story.
content: In 2016 in St. Petersburg, Florida, Maya Kowalski was rushed to the pediatric emergency room for extreme pain. The 10-year-old would be held in the hospital for three months under a state-issued shelter order and barred from seeing her parents, whom doctors suspected of medical child abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How Classified Evidence Could Complicate the Trump Documents Case
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers appear to be preparing for a pretrial fight over showing sensitive evidence to the jury and the public.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have told the judge overseeing his documents case that they have started the process of obtaining security clearances, the first step of what is likely to be a major fight over classified evidence before his trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz, Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Coast Guard Under Scrutiny for Response to Migrant Mass Drowning
description: Contradictions in the Coast Guard’s account cast new doubts over how the Greeks handled one of the worst maritime disasters in the country’s history.
content: ATHENS — Shortly after a rickety fishing boat carrying hundreds of smuggled migrants sank in front of a Greek Coast Guard vessel last week, Greek officials explained that they had not intervened because the smugglers didn’t want them to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: At River to River, Dancers Tackle Weighty Topics With a Smile
description: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council’s free summer arts festival presented several pieces, including “duel c” on Governors Island, that employed humor for serious purposes.
content: Now I know what it is like to be herded by a bassoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Navalny Goes on Trial Again
description: The new extremism charges could add decades to the prison terms that Aleksei Navalny is already serving.
content: A new trial of Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s jailed opposition leader, began on Monday, with several extremism charges potentially adding decades to the prison sentences that he is already serving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupam B. Jena and Christopher M. Worsham
title: The Science of What We Eat Is Failing Us
description: Nutrition science needs a credibility revolution.
content: The World Health Organization recently advised people to avoid using artificial sweeteners for weight loss or to reduce their risk of health issues like heart disease and diabetes. This was based on the agency’s review of available research on artificial sweeteners to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Lewis and Eduardo Medina
title: These Cowboys Build a New Juneteenth Tradition at a Rodeo in Portland
description: The cowboy is “a shorthand for independence and grit and all of these things about America,” an organizer said. “But then you combine it with Black culture, and it just wiggles your brain.”
content: Ivan McClellan, a photographer, was captivated the first time he came across Black cowboy culture at a rodeo in Oklahoma years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Idol’ Season 1, Episode 3 Recap: Tedros Has Notes
description: Turns out that cult-leader types have a lot of opinions about how the women in their lives should look and behave.
content: In her 2022 memoir, “I’m Glad My Mom Died,” the actress Jennette McCurdy wrote candidly about her troubled relationship with her nightmare of a stage mother, who wielded power over every aspect of her life and career. Talking to The New York Times, McCurdy explained the somewhat shocking title she chose for her book, saying, “I feel like I’ve done the processing and put in the work to earn a title or a thought that feels provocative.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Brooklyn’s Juneteenth: Red Velvet Cake and a Slice of History
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 19, 2023.
content: “I had to walk through and just say thank you to my ancestors. We need to enjoy it, because that’s what they would want us to do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Can’t Repeat the Past? An Immersive ‘Great Gatsby’ Thinks You Can.
description: The theatrical performance of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1925 novel, opening this month at the Park Central Hotel, is the latest in a very long, heavily sequined line of “Gatsby” adaptations.
content: In the formerly deserted ballroom of a Midtown Manhattan hotel, on a morning in early May, work lights shone on piles of tile and metal debris. A gramophone stood atop a table beside bolts of shimmering cloth. Artificial flowers spilled from bins. A stack of old-timey suitcases reached the ceiling. Plastic coated the carpets. Dust coated the plastic. In just a month, the doors of this space were scheduled to open onto opulent interiors, meant to evoke the moneyed New York of a century ago. For now, I counted a dozen separate folding ladders and choked on the particulate swirling in the air of this construction zone. Ain’t we got fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Sinykin
title: Cormac McCarthy Had a Remarkable Literary Career. It Could Never Happen Now.
description: The writer had a famously improbable ride to stardom. The fact that he ever escaped obscurity is a testament to just how serendipitous his path was.
content: Cormac McCarthy, who died last week at 89, had a famously unusual career. His first five novels, published over two decades, earned him considerable critical respect but were commercial failures. At one time, all of his books, including his 1985 masterpiece, “Blood Meridian,” fell out of print.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phillip Maciak
title: Meet TV’s 13-Foot-Tall Man
description: The giant teenager in Boots Riley’s new series, “I’m a Virgo” is among television’s boldest moves in a while.
content: Brobdingnag is somewhere in the Pacific Northwest. On the map included in Volume II of his 1726 satire “Gulliver’s Travels,” Jonathan Swift depicts it as an enormous peninsula somewhere north of California. Brobdingnag is the land of the giants: When Gulliver is shipwrecked there, he finds a race of people nearly 60 feet tall, wise and moral, repulsed by his descriptions of a venal and warlike British society. The West Coast no longer teems with such gentle giants, but according to the writer, director and musician Boots Riley, there remains one well south of Brobdingnag, near the spot Swift designates P. Monterey — there’s a giant living in Oakland, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: G.O.P. Leaders Embrace Early Voting, but Will Their Base Get on Board?
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has said that until Republicans gain power and can change the law, they have “no choice” but to support voting by mail.
content: After years of deriding early and mail-in voting, claiming they lead to fraud and help Democrats to steal elections, top Republicans are changing their position, leading to a split in the party as the 2024 election approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: At Least 5 Palestinians Killed in Clashes After Israeli Raid in West Bank
description: A 15-year-old boy was among the dead and dozens more were wounded, Palestinian officials said. Eight Israeli security officers were hurt and helicopters were later deployed, the military reported.
content: An Israeli raid into the city of Jenin in the occupied West Bank turned deadly on Monday, with at least five Palestinians killed in a gun battle, and Israeli helicopter gunships were sent into the area for the first time in decades to secure forces trying to extricate armored vehicles that had been disabled by a powerful roadside bomb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Fossils Show How Long-Necked Reptiles Lost Their Heads
description: The discovery suggests that long necks, which helped some prehistoric reptiles catch food, were tempting targets for predators.
content: In 1830, Henry De la Beche, an English paleontologist, composed a painting of “Duria Antiquior,” a vision of Mesozoic oceans. When picturing a long-necked marine reptile, he depicted its throat clamped between the jaws of a monstrous Ichthyosaurus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​North Korea Criticizes Officials for Failed Satellite Launch​
description: Top political leaders said the botched May 31 launch, which was meant to put a military spy satellite in orbit, had been “irresponsibly” planned.
content: North Korea’s top political leaders “bitterly criticized” officials responsible for a botched attempt to launch a military satellite last month and ordered them to try again, state media reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Rory McIlroy Just Misses a Hollywood Ending at the U.S. Open
description: Despite briefly sharing the lead with the eventual champion, Wyndham Clark, McIlroy settled for second but vowed he would get a fifth major title.
content: It might have been fitting if someone from Holywood won this year’s U.S. Open at Los Angeles Country Club. But Rory McIlroy, born in the Northern Ireland town of Holywood, is not having that kind of year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below the Belt’ and a Juneteenth Celebration
description: A new documentary from Hillary Clinton about living with endometriosis is on PBS, and a commemoration of Black survival and culture streams live on CNN and OWN.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: With Commuters Staying Home, Transit Agencies Try to Reinvent Themselves
description: In California, Bay Area Rapid Transit has suffered so much that it needs a state bailout — and possibly a new business model.
content: Rush hour is now anything but at the Montgomery Street station in the heart of San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: The U.S. worries about private Chinese companies aiding Russia, Blinken says.
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he urged Chinese officials “to be vigilant” as Washington continues to express concerns over possible military support to Russia.
content: BEIJING — While the United States has seen no sign that the Chinese government has decided to send lethal aid to Russia, it is worried that private Chinese companies will provide matériel and technology that Moscow’s military could use in Ukraine, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: A Swiss Army Knife of a Dancer, Making a Virtue of Versatility
description: Gaby Diaz, a winner of “So You Think You Can Dance,” has shaped a surprising freelance career that bridges commercial and concert dance.
content: Dance polyglots abound in the entertainment industry. Need a dancer who can pick up hip-hop and contemporary choreography quickly, and maybe also perform in pointe shoes? At most Los Angeles dance auditions, you’ll find not one but several.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: The Art of Being a Flâneur
description: Sometimes the best way to explore a city on foot is to simply wander, with no goal in mind other than to follow the sound of church bells, or drift across a leafy square.
content: Your “first care must be to ignore the very dream of haste, walking everywhere very slowly and very much at random,” Henry James advised visitors to Perugia, the capital of the Umbria region in Italy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: A Walk in Seoul: Following the Fortress Wall
description: Soak in centuries of history by strolling the Seoul City Wall, which rises high into the mountains.
content: To walk along the Seoul City Wall is to walk in the footsteps of scholars of bygone centuries, trace scars of war and take in the modern behemoth of a city built around it all. Its history stretches back to 1396, to when present-day Seoul first became the capital of what was then a kingdom called Joseon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chitnis
title: A Walk in Paris: Gardens, Greenery and Flower Shops
description: Paris is a city of gardens and a walk through it should leave plenty of time to stop and smell the flowers. This one does.
content: This floral-focused stroll in Paris is the favorite of Sandra Sigman, the celebrated florist and author of the book “French Blooms,” about the distinctive French style of flower arrangement. Just short of three miles, it weaves through the gardens, green spaces and flower shops of the 6th and 7th arrondissements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: The Tropicana, a Relic on the Las Vegas Strip, Could Be Demolished
description: The Tropicana Las Vegas, built in 1957, held the city’s longest-running cabaret and was synonymous with its swinging midcentury glory. It could be torn down to make way for a baseball stadium.
content: In 1957, the Tropicana opened as the most lavish hotel and casino in Las Vegas, with a cascading 60-foot fountain and shimmering pool that piped Muzak underwater. The magicians Siegfried and Roy debuted there; Sean Connery’s James Bond stayed the night; and the Corleones of “The Godfather” took over. Feathered showgirls danced in its Folies Bergère cabaret, and the Tropicana became synonymous with the Strip’s swinging midcentury glory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of June 12, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Yeomans
title: In Wales, Roaming a Land of Legends
description: Walking 36 miles through the Welsh countryside, a writer considers a proposed new national forest, which is designed to help tackle climate change, boost biodiversity and promote nature tourism.
content: Nine hundred years ago, the Lord Rhys, ruler of the ancient Deheubarth kingdom, established a great seat of religious learning in the heart of mid-Wales. The abbey was called Ystrad Fflur (Strata Florida in the Latin spoken by the Cistercian monks who ran it). It means Vale of the Flowers in English.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Vivid Riley
title: 2023 Is the Year of the Long Walk
description: The 500-mile Camino de Santiago has inspired a host of new treks in places from Canada to Bhutan that let travelers take the slow route. Here, a guide to the new trails.
content: The idea of a walking holiday — a long-distance journey on foot, during which you lodge overnight and carry just enough clothing, food and water for each day’s stretch — has long been popular in Europe. But within the last few years, these pilgrimage-style walks have sprung up all over the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Tabor
title: The Homes of Lowndes County, Ala., Are Waiting
description: The county is hardly the only place in America plagued with sanitation problems.
content: For generations, the residents of Lowndes County, Ala. — a rural, mostly Black community bordering Montgomery — have lacked access to adequate sanitation. Many people funnel the sewage from their homes directly into their backyards, where it pools atop the dense, clay-like soil. The area has seen a resurgence of hookworm, which thrives in areas with poor sanitation. The parasite can drain people of their energy and impair cognitive development in children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Lloyd Wright concrete-block house in Los Angeles, a recently renovated home in Sonoma and a three-story retreat in a gated community in Carmel.
content: This house, which has twice appeared on the cover of Architectural Digest, was designed by Lloyd Wright, after working with his father, Frank Lloyd Wright, on the Hollyhock House, one of Wright’s most significant Los Angeles buildings. It is half a block north of Sunset Boulevard, in the Sunset Square Historic Protection Overlay Zone. Hollywood & Highland, the shopping-and-dining complex, is a little more than a mile away. Driving to downtown Los Angeles takes about half an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Should Gig Workers Be Classified?
description: Readers discuss how freelance workers should get benefits. Also: A Trump win-lose scenario; World Heritage sites; climate and the young.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
title: Digging Up Old Graves to Make Room for Newly Fallen Soldiers
description: Funerals have taken on a grim routine in the Ukrainian city of Lviv, and as the fighting grows more intense during the counteroffensive, gravediggers say they are bracing for more bodies.
content: For close to 15 months, the bodies of fallen soldiers have steadily filled up a hillside military cemetery in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv. Now, the old, unmarked graves of those killed in past wars are being exhumed to make way for the seemingly endless stream of dead since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Pearson
title: The Gear You Need to Hit the Trail
description: Whether you’re planning an afternoon walk through city streets, a multiday trek on a pilgrimage route, or something in between, here’s what you’ll need.
content: From strolling the boulevards of Buenos Aires to hiking in the Canadian Rockies, walking provides good exercise while stretching your mind and soul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Shorto
title: A Walk Through the Past in New York
description: Ahead of next year’s 400th anniversary of the Dutch colony of New Netherland, the historian and author of “The Island at the Center of the World” offers a walking tour of often-overlooked Native American and Black sites.
content: In the 19 years since my book “The Island at the Center of the World,” about the Dutch settlement that preceded New York, came out, I’ve changed the way I think about the history and geography of New Amsterdam, which occupied the southern tip of Manhattan Island in the 1600s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elyse Inamine
title: Hawaii’s ‘Local Food,’ a Rich Mix That Isn’t Strictly Hawaiian
description: A blend of influences and ingredients from the many groups who have settled there, this cooking tradition is still sparking creativity, and some complications.
content: In Honokaʻa, on the north side of the Big Island of Hawaii, the firefighters and paramedics at Station 8 can’t predict when the alarm will blare, but they know that if Maikaʻi Piʻianaiʻa is on duty, they’ll eat well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon and Nicole Hong
title: Germany and China Try to Reset Relations for a Changed World
description: This week the two countries will restart government consultations after a pandemic hiatus, but amid the war in Ukraine and rising U.S., Chinese tensions, common ground may be elusive.
content: BERLIN — When Germany and China launched their government consultations a decade ago, Angela Merkel was still chancellor and their relations seemed an endless opportunity for trade and profit. The dialogues were a time for pomp and circumstance, trade deals and signing ceremonies, red carpets and military salutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Declares Day of Mourning for Migrant Ship Disaster Off Greece
description: Officials say more than 100 Pakistanis were among those killed when a fishing boat overloaded with migrants capsized in deep Mediterranean waters. The death toll of the disaster is expected to rise.
content: Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif of Pakistan declared Monday a day of mourning for Pakistanis who died after a fishing boat crowded with migrants capsized off the coast of Greece last week, and ordered a crackdown on the people involved in trafficking Pakistanis to Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Stodghill
title: A Walk in St. Louis: A New African American Trail
description: A two-mile section of the city’s Brickline Greenway project explores the past and future of the city’s Black community.
content: A few hundred yards from the entrance to CityPark, the splashy new soccer stadium in downtown St. Louis, another urban landmark looms: a cluster of hour-glass-shaped sculptures called “Pillars of the Valley,” by the local artist Damon Davis, that pays tribute to some 20,000 residents of a Black community that was forced from this location in 1959 to make way for a freeway. Standing amid its pillars on a recent afternoon, I leaned in close to read a former resident’s inscription in the stone: “What we lost in the destruction of our Mill Creek Valley neighborhood was a community we relied on to survive.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: DeSantis Raises Cash in California and Pokes at Governor
description: The Florida governor made a fund-raising stop in Sacramento not far from the home of Gov. Gavin Newsom. The two are in the midst of a mutually beneficial feud.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who is running for the Republican presidential nomination, took his campaign into the backyard of his most vocal Democratic critic on Monday, courting donors at an event near the home of Gov. Gavin Newsom of California weeks after sending two planeloads of migrants to California’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Tornado Hits Central Mississippi, Killing at Least 1
description: The circumstances surrounding the death were not yet known. Weather officials believe multiple tornadoes may have struck the state overnight.
content: At least one person was killed and 19 others were injured after a tornado slammed central Mississippi overnight and destroyed up to 30 structures, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: Juneteenth in Brooklyn: Red Velvet Cake Served With a Side of History
description: “Hey, we’re still here”: At a time when Black families have been leaving New York, the weekend celebration cultivated a sense of community.
content: All afternoon, people lined up for Shelly Flash’s specialties: jerk cheese nachos and jerk chicken dinner tacos — that’s chicken, coconut rice, black beans, sweet plantains, pickled slaw, chipotle aioli and jerk sour cream inside a soft tortilla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Uruguay’s President Halts Plan to Turn Bronze Nazi Eagle Into Peace Dove
description: President Luis Lacalle Pou said that he was canceling a project to melt down and recast a 700-pound relic of World War II after thousands signed a petition calling for it to be preserved in a museum.
content: Two days after announcing a plan to turn a 700-pound Nazi sculpture of an eagle holding a swastika into a peace dove, the Uruguayan president, Luis Lacalle Pou, said that the project had been canceled after thousands signed a petition calling for it to go to a museum instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: This Little Amsterdam Improv Club Launched Big American Careers
description: Seth Meyers, Jordan Peele, Amber Ruffin and some of the Ted Lasso creators honed their comedy chops thousands of miles from the United States at Boom Chicago, which is turning 30 this year.
content: Seth Meyers had no idea what to expect when he got a job in 1997 performing at a fledgling comedy club in Amsterdam called Boom Chicago. He was in his early 20s, and had never traveled outside of the United States. He had to apply for a passport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: A Walk in Rio de Janeiro: Along Fabled Beaches
description: A five-mile stretch along Copacabana and Ipanema beaches crackles with energy.
content: For first-timers, a five-mile stroll along Copacabana and Ipanema beaches — Rio de Janeiro’s two most fabled sand parentheses — will stir up feelings even in those who have long and unironically listed “walks on the beach” as a favorite pastime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Another Blow to Boris Johnson as U.K. Parliament Ratifies Damning Report
description: The former prime minister will lose his pass to Parliament, another stinging penalty from the fallout of lockdown-breaking parties during the pandemic.
content: Ten days after Boris Johnson abruptly quit Britain’s Parliament, his former colleagues delivered a stinging rebuke to the former prime minister, overwhelmingly ratifying a report that concluded he deliberately misled lawmakers about lockdown-breaking parties held in Downing Street during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez, Jenny Gross, Emma Bubola and Alan Yuhas
title: Vessel Vanishes on Dive to Titanic Wreck, Setting Off a Search
description: A spokesman for the U.S. Coast Guard said the five people on the submersible theoretically had 70 to 96 hours of oxygen before the situation became dire.
content: The submersible vessel carrying five people slipped into the dark waters of the North Atlantic, heading to what remained of the Titanic, 12,500 feet under the sea. The expedition, like many before it, was a testament to the enduring fascination with the storied ship that struck an iceberg and sank off Newfoundland more than a century ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Why Robert Kennedy Jr.’s 2024 Bid Is a Headache for Biden
description: The unexpected polling strength of an anti-vaccine activist with a celebrated Democratic lineage points to the president’s weaknesses, which his team is aiming to shore up.
content: President Biden might seem to be on cruise control until the heat of the 2024 general election. Nearly all of the nation’s top Democrats have lined up behind him, and the Republican nomination fight seems set to revolve around Donald J. Trump’s legal problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Red Rice and Freedom
description: Red foods are traditional for Juneteenth, and we have loads of brightly hued inspiration for you.
content: Today — Juneteenth — marks the recognition of freedom for Africans enslaved in Galveston, Texas, in 1865, more than two years after the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation. Red foods are traditional, and, in the spirit of the holiday, we have loads of brightly hued inspiration for you, whether you make Millie Peartree’s Charleston red rice (above) or Jerrelle Guy’s strawberry pretzel pie. Take a look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Creating a Path for More Black Economists
description: The dearth of Black economists has many causes, but mentorship is clearly part of the solution.
content: In the 2020-21 academic year, Black students accounted for just under 3 percent of the economics doctorates awarded to U.S. citizens and permanent residents, according to the U.S. Department of Education. That was even lower than their 4.8 percent share of doctorates in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) fields, according to the federal data. And there’s been no visible improvement in records going back to 1995. Women, Hispanics and Native Americans are also underrepresented, but I’m going to focus on African Americans in this newsletter in recognition of the Juneteenth federal holiday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: In a First-Grade Classroom, Lessons on Optimism and Climate Change
description: Cara Buckley, a Climate reporter for The New York Times, visited an elementary school in Lawrenceville, N.J., where students are encouraged to talk about complex environmental issues.
content: In June 2020, New Jersey became the first state in the country to mandate climate change education in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 19, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 19, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Tropical Storm Bret Forms in the Atlantic
description: The storm formed Monday east of the Windward Islands, the National Hurricane Center said. It is forecast to strengthen into a hurricane by the end of the week.
content: Tropical Storm Bret formed on Monday, becoming the second named storm of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: In a Flash, How Sasha Calle Became Supergirl
description: The actress, making her feature film debut, discusses auditioning for “The Flash” without being told the role, or movie she was up for.
content: Online, many have seen the moment that the actress Sasha Calle, 27, knew her life had been utterly altered: The director of “The Flash,” Andy Muschietti, announced the casting of Calle as Supergirl by posting the video in which he tells her she got the job, beating out hundreds of others. It would be her feature film debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Alcoba and Sarah Pabst
title: In Argentina, Inflation Passes 100% (and the Restaurants Are Packed)
description: Argentina’s financial crisis has a surprising side effect: a flourishing dining scene in Buenos Aires, as residents rush to spend pesos before they lose more value.
content: Wine glasses clinked in an Art Nouveau culinary gem basking in its restored splendor. It was tasting night in the more than century-old coffeehouse turned restaurant at the old Buenos Aires zoo, as beet tartare, pan-seared squid and a perfect rib-eye floated out of the kitchen, chased by a velvety chocolate mousse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: The Thrill of New York, Despite an Awful Lot of One-Month Rentals
description: In the last year, a woman from Australia has lived on the Lower East Side, in NoLIta, in Chelsea, and in Brooklyn. She finally has a place in Little Italy with roommates.
content: Natasha Pearce had visited New York City only once, for 10 days at the age of 24, before deciding she wanted to leave Australia and make the city her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: Should Medicine Still Bother With Eponyms?
description: The names of Nazi-era doctors are still found on diseases and body parts. By expunging them, will doctors forget lessons of the past?
content: Edith Sheffer’s young son always disliked labels such Asperger’s syndrome. But in 2016, a psychiatrist told him that he should be proud: His condition was named after Dr. Hans Asperger, an Austrian scientist in the 1930s who used his position to help save children like him. By devising a diagnosis that emphasized the children’s intellectual abilities, the psychiatrist said, Dr. Asperger tried to spare them from the Nazi campaign to “euthanize” youths with cognitive disabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Sheera Frenkel
title: G.O.P. Targets Researchers Who Study Disinformation Ahead of 2024 Election
description: A legal campaign against universities and think tanks seeks to undermine the fight against false claims about elections, vaccines and other hot political topics.
content: On Capitol Hill and in the courts, Republican lawmakers and activists are mounting a sweeping legal campaign against universities, think tanks and private companies that study the spread of disinformation, accusing them of colluding with the government to suppress conservative speech online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Jeffrey Epstein Acted Like an Adviser to JPMorgan Executive
description: A court document shows that James E. Staley of JPMorgan Chase consulted with Mr. Epstein, a registered sex offender, on a wide variety of matters.
content: James E. Staley, the former top JPMorgan Chase executive who was closest to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein at the bank, relied on him for many years as almost something of a personal adviser, a document shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Lube That’s Too Chic for the Sock Drawer
description: With minimalist labeling and elegant packaging, a new generation of personal lubricants can seem more self-care than sex aid. Make room on the night stand.
content: For Portia Brown, a sex coach in Brooklyn, lube is nonnegotiable. “I don’t think I’ve had sex in the last five years without reaching for a lubricant,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Xi and Blinken Meet
description: Also, New Zealand slipped into a recession.
content: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, as the two countries try to pull relations out of a deep chill that has raised global concerns about the growing risk of a conflict between them. The talks show that both countries recognize the stakes of their rivalry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Adam Goldman and Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Sought to Kill Defector in Florida
description: A failed plot to assassinate a C.I.A. spy in 2020 in part led to expulsions of the agency’s chief in Moscow and his Russian counterpart in Washington.
content: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has pursued enemies abroad, his intelligence operatives now appear prepared to cross a line that they previously avoided: trying to kill a valuable informant for the U.S. government on American soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Only One State in America Includes the Study of Climate Change for All Grades
description: Schools can teach children how important it is for everyone to help.
content: NASHVILLE — One afternoon in late March, family friends discovered a female cardinal resting on their patio, unable to fly. I couldn’t tell for sure from the photo they sent, but I thought perhaps the bird had flown into a window. I forwarded the picture to the experts at Harmony Wildlife Rehabilitation Center, which is near my friends’ house, and asked for advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and David Pierson
title: Blinken Meets Xi as China and the U.S. Try to Rein in Tensions
description: U.S. diplomats visited Beijing to try to ensure that competition “does not veer into conflict.” The talks pave the way for a possible Biden-Xi meeting.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, on Monday in Beijing, as the two governments sought to pull relations out of a deep chill that has raised global concerns about the growing risk of a conflict between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Scheck and Lara Jakes
title: In Rush to Arm Ukraine, Weapons Are Bought but Not Delivered, or Too Broken to Use
description: Some of the weapons sent to Ukraine by other countries have been unusable, and hundreds of millions of dollars in contracts paid up front have yet to be fulfilled.
content: Ukraine has paid contractors hundreds of millions of dollars for weapons that have not been delivered, and some of the much-publicized arms donated by its allies have been so decrepit that they were deemed fit only to be cannibalized for spare parts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chad Williams
title: On Being Black and American Overseas
description: In “Beyond the Shores,” the historian Tamara J. Walker explores the lives of African Americans drawn to other countries by pleasure, employment and war.
content: In the popular imagination, stories of African American expatriates and travelers to other countries often center on Paris and feature well-known names. We may think of the dancer and singer Josephine Baker, wowing Jazz Age audiences in the City of Light and basking in a freedom she could not enjoy in the United States. Or, perhaps, Black authors like Richard Wright, who moved to the French capital in 1946 and, from that liberatory arrival onward, said he “never felt a moment of sorrow.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Lazar
title: Machines and Morality
description: A conversation with an unhinged Bing made me rethink what gives humans moral value.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: Who do you think you are? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Max Morath, Pianist Who Staged a One-Man Ragtime Revival, Dies at 96
description: A student of both music and history, he entertained audiences in the 1960s and beyond while educating them about a genre whose heyday had ended decades earlier.
content: Max Morath, who stepped out of the 1890s only a lifetime late, and with syncopated piano rhythms and social commentary helped revive the ragtime age on educational television programs, in concert halls and in nightclubs for nearly a half-century, died on Monday at a care facility near his home in Duluth, Minn. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Where Are the 2024 Candidates?
description: With the Republican field mostly set, the contenders are fanning out across the country.
content: With the Republican field mostly set, the contenders are fanning out across the country.
source.name: The New York Times
